data.message: Heading off to college or returning to campus? Be prepared at your new home! http://go.usa.gov/3HBbV

Make sure your emergency kit has food and water that will last at least three days per person.  And don't forget flashlights, batteries, a first aid kit, cell phone chargers, can openers... are you writing this down? #BeReady 

Send the romance e-card to your loved ones: http://t.cdc.gov/ecards/message.aspx?cardid=740&category=158
Have you checked your emergency kit lately? Replace expired items & add what you need. http://go.usa.gov/p69  #BeReady #MondayMotivation

Learn the facts about the Legionnaires outbreak in the South Bronx & what NYC Department Of Health And Mental Hygiene is doing to prevent future outbreaks: http://on.nyc.gov/1KBl5Kx

Follow @nycHealthy on Twitter for updates. https://twitter.com/nycHealthy

As the new #school year quickly approaches, make sure you have everything you need to help your child have a happy and healthy school year, including talking to them about what to do during an emergency at school. http://blogs.cdc.gov/publichealthmatters/2015/08/back-to-school-be-prepared/

As student athletes return to the field, stay healthy in the heat! 

Pace your activities, drink more water than usual, pack on the sunscreen, and keep an eye on the health of your teammates. www.cdc.gov/extremeheat/athletes.html

More rain and flooding lead to evacuations in Tampa, Florida.

If you live in the Tampa area, sign up for Alert Tampa, the city’s official emergency alert system, to receive time sensitive notifications which will be sent directly to your email, cell phone, and in some cases, home phone. Alert Tampa will provide you the official information you can use to keep your business, your home, and your family safe. To sign up today, visit our website at tampagov.net/alerttampa or call (813) 231-6184.

Did you know CDC responds to natural disasters, disease outbreaks, plus chemical, radiological & biological events? 

Find out how CDC is involved in emergencies: http://www.cdc.gov/phpr/whatcdcisdoing.htm

Travelers in Africa should be aware of more than just the threat of malaria when it comes to #mosquitoes. New CDC research has revealed a prevalence of dengue fever cases in Africa that are often misdiagnosed as malaria. Learn more about the research being done to learn how to better diagnose and prevent dengue fever in Africa in our latest blog post.

Heat stress is caused by your body's inability to cool down properly.  The body normally cools itself by sweating. But under some conditions, sweating just isn't enough. In such cases, a person's body temperature rises rapidly. Very high body temperatures may damage the brain or other vital organs. It ranges in conditions from heat rash and cramps to heat exhaustion.

Read more about heat stress: http://www.cdc.gov/media/dpk/2015/dpk-summer-weather.html

Those with asthma or lung conditions should be aware of poor air quality caused by high temperatures. 

Visit the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency 's Air Quality Index when planning outdoor summer activities: www.airnow.gov
Know the difference between a severe weather watch and a severe weather warning: http://go.usa.gov/3gVFF  #BeReady

A tornado doesn’t have to be filled with sharks to be terrifying and dangerous. Get tips on how to prepare for a tornado before you find yourself in one: http://emergency.cdc.gov/disasters/tornadoes/index.asp  #Sharknado3

Heat cramps, heat rash, heat exhaustion and heat stroke are all serious heat illnesses. Know the symptoms and what to do when they occur.  #BeatTheHeat

Our heat guide has helpful info on symptoms and prevention: http://emergency.cdc.gov/disasters/extremeheat/heat_guide-page-3.asp

Sunburn can slow the skin's ability to release excess heat. Don't forget  #sunscreen and avoid repeated sun exposure.
 
If you have a sunburn, apply cold compresses or immerse the sunburned area in cool water.  You can also apply moisturizing lotion to affected areas. Do not use salve, butter, or ointment. Do not break blisters.

Visit www.cdc.gov/extremeheat for more hot tips. 
 #BeatTheHeat

Don't forget to include your furry family member in your emergency plans. 🐶🐱 Here's a checklist to get you started: 

www.cdc.gov/readywrigley
#WorldEmojiDay

What’s your Ready Rating? Take the quiz from American Red Cross and find out how your business measures up. 

www.readyrating.org

Barber Foods and Omaha Steaks recall frozen, raw chicken entrees linked to Salmonella outbreak. Check your freezer and don’t eat these products. 

Read more about this ongoing investigation: http://go.usa.gov/3fHmJ

Never leave kids or pets alone in closed vehicles.The temperature in your car could be deadly. Beat the heat and check the backseat! 

www.cdc.gov/extremeheat

In July 1995, Chicago experienced a historic and deadly heat wave, with temperatures reaching 104-106˚F. Extreme heat can be dangerous and cause serious health conditions, or even death. Know how to stay healthy and cool during a heat wave with tips from CDC and NOAA.

For more information, visit http://cdc.gov/extremeheat or www.weather.gov/heat

The 1995 Chicago Heat Wave was the deadliest weather event in Chicago history. Over 700 people lost their lives due to extreme heat. Know the risk of extreme heat and know how you can prepare for rising summer temperatures. 

For tips on how to beat the heat visit: http://cdc.gov/extremeheat or www.weather.gov/heat

U.S. National Weather Service (NWS)

Extreme heat can be a serious threat to your health. Stay cool and hydrated, and avoid spending time outside during the hottest times of the day. 

For more information on extreme heat, visit www.cdc.gov/extremeheat or www.weather.gov/heat. 

U.S. National Weather Service (NWS)
